content.body: gsnedders: Is there some pun involved?  If not, then pass.
Just the new web, and web.nu is taken
ponders dropping full support for his blog for anything that doesn't support CSS 2.1
Thumbs up from me.
is finding <time> useful just as a justifiable styling hook.
Though I am getting legitimate use out of it too.  Would be better if it stored a unix timestamp, but we can't all be perfect.
But some of the more eccentric things I'd like to use aren't impl in Gecko
As long as it's still readable in gecko, it's cool.
Anne's blog doesn't work right outside of Opera.
Anne's blog doesn't work right _in_ Opera
Really?  Heh, I assumed that he'd been using opera features.
Nah, he's just deliberately using things browsers don't support so he can make them site compat. bugs to try and get them fixed quicker than just standards bugs :)
Ah, I see.  ^_^
(His name should appear in top left, and doesn't in Opera 10)
Gah. IE7 still makes up 50% of visitors from IE. :(
Yup.
What's your ie6 percentage?
25% of IE
So, what, 15% or so of total?  Or are you lucky enough to have a lower-than-normal ie %?
I am, because out of my vanity I account for a disproportionate number of hits to me site :P
Bah, you don't exclude yourself?  Cheater!
I have no easy way to do so :)
dynamic ip?
Dynamic IP and I travel too much at the moment :)
That works.
30% of hits to my site are from Opera, which is a bit out of the normal :)
(The hits from Opera aren't solely me, though, as there are some from versions I don't use.)
(Basically I'm at 30/30/30 between Opera/Firefox/IE)
kk
SimplePie.org is far more interesting from a UA POV as it inevitably gets way more hits from way more people
(3000–5000 hits per day, 500–900 unique)
But that's heavily (67%) Firefox, then 19% Safari, 12% IE, 2% Opera
I require SimplePie now.  Must set it up tonight.
(once I get done working)
(IE8 is the biggest version of IE at 5%, which makes me somewhat tempted to drop support for anything older when we finally redo the site.)
Last time i looked at my company's stats, we were something like 20% ie6, 40% ie7, 10% ie8, 20% ff, and 10% assorted
is sendAsBinary a standard thing on XHR, and does it work anywhere except FF3+?
it seems like a great idea to me
annevk2, annevk3: maybe you know?
Non-standard, AFAIK
yeah, I don't see it in the standard
I wonder if anyone but FF implements it
jacobolus, I think Firefox implemented some extensions
too bad they didn't prefix them :/
annevk2: any idea if anyone else is interested in those?
yeah, but not in that form
and the "binary DOMString" concept is also not very attractive imo
because sendAsBinary is pretty useful; allows us to avoid doing base64 encoding or base85 encoding or similar for sending bytes to a server
annevk2: why not very attractive?
annevk2: it seems like a reasonable solution as long as we don't have any kind of real bytes type in javascript
it seems better to fix the real issue imo
annevk2: in Orbited, we use this sort of "use the lower byte of each 16-bit code unit" thing for representing bytes
it's pretty much the only way to do it in current browsers, without browsers adding a new type
sure, but if browsers are going to implement new features they should fix the actual issues imo and not implement stopgap measures
fair enough :)
annevk2: is there any chance that that will happen? :)
i'd like to thinkso
well if someone convinces some browsers that they should support sending binary data around, that'd be awesome
actually, I'm pretty happy with this particular stop-gap though; it's actually a pretty big improvement over the alternative
